prompt: Facts: Marriage between Bharti (Respondent/Complainant) and Rakesh Chopra solemnized on October 19, 2003.; Bharti allegedly left her matrimonial home on January 15, 2004.; Bharti filed a complaint with the Crime Against Women (CAW) Cell on April 1, 2004, alleging harassment and dowry demands.; Allegations were made against the husband (Rakesh Chopra), father-in-law, mother-in-law, sister-in-law (Neelu Chopra - Appellant No. 1), and brother-in-law (Marrying Chopra - Appellant No. 2).; FIR No. 605/2004 was registered on August 13, 2004, at PS Punjabi Bagh, Delhi under Sections 498A and 406 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).; The specific allegations against the Appellants (Neelu and Marrying Chopra) in the FIR were general and omnibus in nature, lacking specific details about their individual roles or acts of cruelty/demand.; The Appellants filed a petition under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) before the High Court of Delhi seeking quashing of the FIR against them.; The High Court dismissed the petition, leading to the appeal before the Supreme Court.; Judicial Observation (Supreme Court): Noted the tendency to involve all relatives in dowry harassment cases, often with vague allegations.; Judicial Observation (Supreme Court): Stressed the need for specific allegations against each accused person for criminal proceedings to continue, especially under Section 498A IPC. | IPC: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 406 (Punishment for criminal breach of trust), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) - Implicitly relevant due to multiple accused, though not the focus of the quashing petition.
